title: Between 1 October 2018 and 30 September 2019, will an armed group from the Democratic Republic of Congo engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Democratic Republic of Congo?
preds: For those who may be interested in a deeper dive, the Early Warning Project published a blogpost yesterday (just before the announcement of the election postponement to December 30): https://www.ushmm.org/confront-genocide/genocide-prevention-blog/atrocity-risk-in-congo-increases-as-elections-near *Note that this is an EWP staff account. We post relevant articles and engage in discussions with forecasters. However, we always forecast the current consensus so as not to influence participants' forecasts in either direction.

Updating forecast with the following points: Increase liklihood:
- Nobel laureate from Congo, Denis Mukwege noting the government seems to be preparing for conflict: "There is very little electoral preparation and a lot of military preparation. I am very worried that these elections will not be free, fair, credible and peaceful and that if there are massive frauds .... supporters (from losing candidates) will not accept them. "
(https://www.reuters.com/article/us-nobel-prize-peace/nobel-peace-prize-laureate-mukwege-worried-congo-vote-could-lead-to-war-idUSKBN1O91FD) Reduce Liklihood:
- Prior for EWP of 30.9% is through the end of 2019 while this forecast only runs through end of September next year, per @RachelS 's comment (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/795878)

Prior probability: EWP forecasts a 30.9% chance of a mass killing in the DRC in the next year (https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/democratic-republic-of-congo). Thank you @RachelS for pointing out my previous forecast (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/795765) used the probability of the Republic of Congo instead! Increase Liklihood (in order of weight):
- Congo Elections held on Dec 23, would be first transition of power to new government 
- - Increased instability if new government as transition takes place. 
- -Lower trust by populace if government does not transition or elections are unsuccessful.
- Kidnapping of people critical of current government (https://www.channelstv.com/2018/12/09/anti-kabila-rapper-abducted-in-dr-congo/)
- Reduced US counterterrorism troop presence in Africa (https://www.cnn.com/2018/11/15/politics/us-reduce-troops-africa/index.html) 
- ISIS / other militants presence (https://www.cnn.com/2018/12/03/politics/isis-threat-us-embassy-drc/index.html)  Decrease Liklihood: 
- Verbal commitment to elections by government (https://reliefweb.int/report/democratic-republic-congo/security-council-press-statement-electoral-preparations-democratic) 
- UN helping to ensure elections are successful (same link as above)
- Ebola outbreak causing increased international aid / involvement (https://www.usaid.gov/news-information/press-releases/oct-1-2018-usaid-spokesperson-mccleskey-deployment-dart-drc-ebola) (credit: @Anneinak)

The long-delayed elections are approaching, and although this is often portrayed as preventing further violence, it could trigger a new wave of clashes. The question pivots on whether one group will be motivated to target another. Given that the existing political and social conditions are ripe for conflict, large-scale violence can break-out suddenly and for seemingly minor reasons. If the outcome of elections is disputed, or leaves one or more party aggrieved, the approaching election could be one of these  reasons, especially if there is perception of fraud.        Source:  https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/11/27/is-kabila-using-ethnic-violence-to-stay-in-power/
       Source: https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/08/03/will-congo-go-to-the-polls-or-go-to-war-kabila-drc-rwanda-kivu/

There are 70 to 80 armed groups in the DRC more than 4 million people are displaced fleeing violence. The irrational and fanatic ethnic hatred between Hutu and Tutsi has spilled over into DRC from Rwanda.  The most likely culprit in a mass slaughter would be the M23, Tutsis with some financial backing from the Rwandan govt. who are now essentially separatists. Despite the presence of U.N. peacekeepers (roughly 15,000)...The FDA (Force Democratique Aliees an Ugandan militia who claim that they want an African 'Islamic State'  have engaged in mass killings in an efficient militaristic fashion. They killed several U.N. peacekeepers last month. Weak leadership; old ethnic rivalries, a history of violence, opportunistic warlords and terrorist leaders flowing into the Congo.  A bad recipe.

General country statistics / history put the country at 4.3% chance according to EWP (https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/republic-of-the-congo) Increase Liklihood:
- Ebola Outbreak, reducing stablity (https://www.keyt.com/health/ebola-cases-surge-in-congo/915536703)
- ISIS / other militants presence (https://www.cnn.com/2018/12/03/politics/isis-threat-us-embassy-drc/index.html)
- Reduced US counterterrorism troop presence in Africa (https://www.cnn.com/2018/11/15/politics/us-reduce-troops-africa/index.html)
- Congo Elections held on Dec 23, would be first transition of power to new government
    - Increased instability if new government
    - Lower trust by populace if government does not transition or elections are unsuccessful Decrease Liklihood:
- Government seems commited elections (https://reliefweb.int/report/democratic-republic-congo/security-council-press-statement-electoral-preparations-democratic)
- UN helping to ensure elections are successful (same link as above)

The significant surge in violence within the Democratic Republic of Congo means that loose-triggered militias and even government troops are somewhat likely to carry out killings on such a scale. The recent violence against relatively mild political opposition is an indication that this is more likely than some may think. Any group that becomes identified with political opposition in DRC would be particularly susceptible to mass killings.
